title: Yen Gains, Japan Stocks Drop After Trump Comments: Markets Wrap - Bloomberg
text:
President-elect failed to provide policy details in speech Drugmakers slide in Japan as Trump criticizes pharma industry 
The yen strengthened for a fourth day and Japanese stocks retreated after Donald Trump’s first press conference since his election victory gave scant detail on policy. Shares of commodity producers climbed after crude oil surged. The most important market news of the day. Get our markets daily newsletter. You will now receive the Game Plan newsletter Drugmakers and exporters dragged Japanese equities lower after Trump criticized the pharmaceutical industry and as the currency extended gains against the dollar. Hong Kong stocks held near a two-month high, while industrial companies led gains in Australian shares. Asia’s regional equity index rose for a fourth day, poised for the highest closing level since October. Oil was little changed following the biggest rally in more than a month.
U.S. President elect Trump said he’d force the pharmaceutical industry to bid for government business in the world’s largest drug market, where Japanese firms do substantial business. Trump’s first press conference since July left investors with little detail on the timing and scope of planned policies from infrastructure spending to trade pacts. Since his victory, the dollar and global equities have rallied, while bonds sold off amid expectations growth will get a kick higher from his administration’s actions. 
“The market did have some hopes that Trump will give more details on his policies. The yen’s moves do reflect that disappointment,” said Masakuni Fujiwara, chief executive officer at VistaMax Fund Advisors Ltd. in Tokyo. “Health-care shares have been impacted by Mr. Trump’s comments, but they’ve also been significantly bought up these past few years.” 
Read more from our Markets Live blog here. 
Stocks The MSCI Asia Pacific Index rose 0.7 percent as of 10:57 a.m. in Tokyo, with an almost equal number of shares advancing and declining. Japan’s Topix index lost 0.6 percent. Takeda Pharmaceutical Co. traded 2.8 percent lower, Chugai Pharmaceutical Co. lost 2.6 percent and Astellas Pharma Inc. dropped 3.8 percent. Australia’s S&P/ASX 200 Index and South Korea’s Kospi index climbed at least 0.2 percent. New Zealand’s S&P/NZX 50 Index fell 0.2 percent. BHP Billiton shares were up 1.7 percent. The Shanghai Composite Index added 0.2 percent while Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index was little changed. Futures on the S&P 500 Index slid 0.1 percent. The underlying gauge increased 0.3 percent on Wednesday, staging an afternoon rally and recouping losses of as much as 0.4 percent. 
Currencies The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index, a gauge of the greenback against 10 major peers, fell 0.1 percent, a second day of losses. It’s advanced less than 0.2 percent since the Fed’s rate decision on Dec. 14. The yen rose 0.3 percent to 115.04 per dollar after advancing 0.3 percent Wednesday. The Aussie added 0.1 percent to 74.49 U.S. cents after climbing 1 percent Wednesday, while the kiwi increased 0.1 percent to 70.62 U.S. cents after rising 0.9 percent in the last session. 
Commodities West Texas Intermediate crude slipped less than 0.1 percent, after climbing 2.8 percent Wednesday, rising the most since Dec. 1 after a government report showed U.S. refiners processed a record amount of crude last week. Gold rose 0.3 percent, a fourth day of gains to trade near the highest level since November. Before it's here, it's on the Bloomberg Terminal.
